Abstract
The influence of pragmatism on institutionalism, and in particular on
that of John Commons, is now widely recognized.

In particular, the importance of rules and habits in behavior has been well
highlighted in pragmatism. However, the importance, in this school of thought, of thinking about the break or rupture with respect to rules and habits has been downplayed.

This article highlights that John Dewey, one of the most influential pragmatists, thought of these transformations.
He analyzes them based on three key concepts: experience,
transaction, and emotion. This provides a new line of thought for economic analysis,
particularly in the role that emotions can play in changes in
relation to rules and habits of behavior. Dewey thus invites us to a richer economy of emotion
than economic analysis has produced so far. Keywords: Pragmatism, institution, transaction, emotion, transformation.

This focus on habits has however left aside the role 
of emotions in this school of thought. Barbalet (2008) emphasizes in particular that emotions in William James constitute a key concept. They are a precondition for action and interaction 
and cannot be summed up as a simple feeling. Still according to Barbalet

to be clearly different from the pragmatism of George Herbert Mead

more in agreement with William James, but offers an original analysis that seems to us to clearly open a door to a new reading of the economy of emotions. We argue that

As Albert and Ramstad (1997) point out, both authors subscribe to non-dualist thinking, place the notion of “transaction” at the heart of their theory, and make habit an essential determinant of individual behavior. In John Dewey, we find, as early as the 1890s (notably in the articles of 1894, 1895, 1896) and then in his work published in 
1922 – Human Nature and Conduct: Introduction to Social Psychology – a 
first sketch (which will be developed in particular in Art as

transformation of individual habits. In 1934, in Institutional 
Economics: Its in Political Economy, John Commons will recognize the

of institutionalist theory. 
We begin by recalling that John Dewey develops above all a philosophy of experience (2). Then, we emphasize that it
establishes an important distinction between interaction and transaction.
This distinction allows us to read the dynamics of institutions as a mechanism of co-evolution (3).

We then highlight that emotions play a major role in the philosophy of experience
in John Dewey; and also that emotions can cause bifurcations in the dynamics of institutions precisely because this dynamic is forged in a transaction process (4). Finally, we show that reading Dewey allows us to go beyond the standard approach to the economy of emotions and, above all, that it can be a source of inspiration for institutionalist economics
(5).
2. A PHILOSOPHY OF EXPERIENCE
Associated with the pragmatist philosophical school, around Charles
Sanders Peirce (1839-1914) and William James (1842-1910), well-known for his commitment to the sphere of education, John
Dewey develops an original approach that can be summarized under the name of the philosophy of experience. This philosophy is
generally interpreted as anti-foundationalism, i.e.

the fact

our knowledge by basing it on a fixed and unquestionable foundation (Shusterman 1994).

The post-foundationalist philosophy he proposes "should be a form of cultural criticism that aims to redescribe our experience of the world and to reconstruct our practices and institutions in order to improve the quality of our lives. The improvement of experience, not original truth, is the ultimate philosophical goal and criterion" (Shusterman 1994, 27, our translation). Certainly, Dewey's use of the very notion of experience has been the subject of much criticism (for example, in Rorty 1992) but it shows a strong originality in its desire to go beyond the classical dualism in philosophy between mind and matter (Shusterman 1994). Dewey clarified his argument in particular
in Experience and Nature (2012) and in two articles The Experimental
Theory of Knowledge (1906a) and The Reality as Experience (1906b). These
writings focus largely on scientific knowledge. Dewey
notes the turning point taken by knowledge, in particular with Francis Bacon, who broke with the notion of experience in Antiquity. While
in Antiquity, experience is what comes from the past and forges
what we must do (in the sense of the wisdom of experience), with
Francis Bacon experience turns towards the future and the need
to improve knowledge. Dewey then emphasizes that experience
is always marked by incompleteness and dynamics (Truc2005).
His conception of experience is not limited to a simple positivist
empiricism. Experience is not carried out by a passive observer
because it is a moment of transformation, transformation of reality and of the one who carries out the "observation". It is certainly through
the aesthetic experience in an essay published in 1934, Art as
Experience 2, that Dewey best formulates his philosophy of experience.
We will rely on this text to highlight its main characteristics.
According to John Dewey, "[T]here is constantly experience, because
the interaction of the living being and its environment is part
of the very process of existence" (AE, 80). This does not mean,
naturally, that everything is subject to experience, or that every experience
is successful or accomplished.

Chez John Dewey, l’unité de l’expérience est cependant davantage 
celle d’un « évènement »  mobile, fragile, traversé de tensions 
contradictoires  qui sont momentanément  maîtrisées, jamais totalement 
stabilisées. L’expérience  est en ce sens rarement close, fermée sur elle-
même, car son unité constitue un processus en développement qui, 
arrivé à son point culminant, se dissout dans le flot de l’expérience 
suivante. L’unité est construite « à partir des débris et des vestiges des 
expériences passées et des ressources du présent » (Shusterman 2018, 
95) et nous invite, continument,  à développer d’autres expériences. La 
prise en compte de la temporalité  de l’expérience et de son insertion dans 
un processus toujours renouvelé  constitue sa cinquième caractéristique 
essentielle.
En résumé, Chez John Dewey, la notion d’expérience  fait référence 
à une activité de transformation  d’une relation entre un sujet et son 
environnement  qui intervient à la suite d’un « trouble » ou d’un 
dysfonctionnement.  Chez l’artiste, par exemple, le travail consiste 
concrètement  en l’agencement  de matériaux divers – le peintre dispose 
des pigments sur sa toile, l’écrivain compose par l’intermédiaire  de 
mots ce qu’il veut dire, le sculpteur conçoit sa statue à partir d’argile, 
de marbre ou de bronze. Entre la conception et la concrétisation de l’œuvre (l’objet), il y a une longue période de gestation et d’allers-
retours entre le sujet (l’artiste) et le matériau concret (le texte, les 
pigments sur la toile, les harmonies musicales, etc.) qui est au cœur de 
l’expérience.
Si Dewey voit dans l’expérience esthétique le cas le plus exemplaire 
de l’expérience,  cette dernière est présente dans tous nos actes 
ordinaires, qu’il s’agisse de nos relations familiales, de nos choix de 
consommation ou de production, ou encore de notre rapport au marché. Dans Expérience et Nature  (2012), il illustre parfaitement la large 
palette de l’expérience avec l’exemple de l’expérience de la mort. Cette 
expérience, plus exactement son anticipation,  nous dit-il, joue un rôle 
fondamental dans des domaines aussi divers que les religions ou le développement  des compagnies d’assurance. En ce sens l’expérience 
de la mort provoque des évolutions aussi bien dans le cadre de la vie intime que dans celui de la vie économique.

3.

INTERACTION, TRANSACTION, AND RULES
For John Dewey, experience is a continuous process of
changes, as much as it is the way in which we experience these
changes. This concept of experience is completed by that of
transaction. In John Dewey’s analysis, the environment
and the organism are immersed in a process of adjustment and
reciprocal exchanges. Their mutual relations do not arise
from a causal logic, but rather from an “interaction”. Here, the terms organism and environment “are strictly correlative,
as are those of brother and sister, buyer and seller,
stimulus and response” (Zask2015a) so that when Dewey speaks
of a subject, he is indeed, in a form that is in no way reductionist,
of a human organism that is radically transformed upon contact
with others or with its environment.
However, John Dewey preferred to use, in his writings, the term
“transaction” (Steiner2010, 208) between the organism and
the environment rather than that of “interaction”. John Dewey clarifies
this choice in a letter addressed to his co-author, Arthur Bentley, in 1942: "The term "interaction" is dangerous, since
it is easy to understand that it involves two or more
previous existences" (Ibid., 205). The term "interaction" suggests
indeed that the organism and the environment are connected and
relative to each other but does not imply that their internal composition is
itself dependent on their interrelations. In order to better reflect
this idea, Dewey opted, at the end of his collaboration with
Arthur Bentley in 1949, for the term "transaction". The authors
explain the difference in these terms:
If interaction assumes that the organism and the objects in
its environment are present as substantially separate existences or forms of
existence, before they enter into a common investigation, then – the Transaction does not assume any prior knowledge of either the organism or the environment alone
as adequate, not even as regards the fundamental nature of the conventional distinctions between them, but requires

During the transaction process, the entities that interact are themselves likely to be modified. In the case suggested above of the artist, the subject is himself transformed by his creative act as much as by the transaction to which the concrete material (words, pigments, musical notes) subjects him. The transaction is this process by which the parties present are simultaneously transformed by their presence. While interaction is summed up as
separate parties producing something during their exchange, and stops after the exchange, transaction assumes that exchange is
the constitutive element of the simultaneous transformation of the parties, and this
continuously. Transaction therefore assumes that we take into account how the relationship between the subject and its environment has
been constructed over time. Transaction therefore integrates the history of the relationship. Transaction therefore completes the
concept of experience in the sense that, if experience is a process
of transformation, this process is a simultaneous transformation of the environment and of the organism that acts with (and not on)
the environment (because the organism is as much acted by the environment
as it acts on). At this point, we can set a milestone regarding the role that
John Dewey gives to rules, habits and routines (see also Garreta 2002).
A good illustration of his point of view is found in his interpretation of the role of culture.

John Dewey not only wrote a text on culture, Freedom and Culture (1939), but 
he also had an influence on cultural anthropology. He led a joint seminar at Columbia University with Franz Boas and participated in the training of anthropologists such as Ruth Benedict and Leslie White. His writings on culture have also been the subject of fairly recent rereadings (Brereton 2009; Goldman 2012; Colón & Hobbs 2015). Dewey shares with anthropologists of this period a conception of culture as a coherent and open functional system (Zask 2015b).
By this we mean that culture is a set of rules and habits whose purpose is to respond to practical problems that societies pose.
The system is functional in this sense.

It is coherent because the different

areas of life are related and culture intertwines them. Finally, it is open, and this is the most important point
for our discussion, because individuals are not automatons who conform to rules and follow habits.
They are also rule makers (as they are made in part by rules through habits).

Culture, as a system, aims to provide solutions to practical problems. When the
system no longer satisfies practical problems, changes occur. These changes are the result of a transaction between
individuals and the system (organisms and their environment) so that both are modified, the system by changes
in cultural practices, and individuals by the emergence of new rules, habits, that they follow. It is in this sense that in The
Public and Its Problems (2010), Dewey considers democratic participation to be
fundamental (Zask 1999).

Dewey cannot be read simply as
an author who attributes a major role to rules or habits, he is
above all a thinker of change in rules and habits.
4. EMOTIONS IN DEWEY
John Dewey largely opposed
dualist and rationalist forms throughout his life.
In particular, he proposed a rich and elaborate non-dualist conception of emotion which is at the heart of the notion of "experience" and the "transactional" phenomenon presented above.

Au début de sa carrière, Dewey (1894 ; 1895 ; 
1896) propose une psychologie fonctionnelle  de l’émotion, combinant 
(tout en critiquant) les apports de Darwin (1998) et de James (1884). On trouve dès ses premiers écrits et, notamment dans les articles de 1894 et 1895, l’idée que l’émotion « est une disposition, un mode 
de conduite, une façon de se comporter »  (Dewey 1895,  172, nous 
traduisons), qui possède une « visée » (Ibid., 171, nous traduisons). Dans la continuité de ces premiers travaux, mais aussi en s’écartant 
d’une conception purement psychologique  fonctionnelle,  Dewey 
(2005) examine la place fondamentale  de l’émotion (et de sa qualité) 
au cours de l’expérience (Quéré 2018).  L’émotion, dans son entièreté, 
correspond toujours à un « mode de conduite qui poursuit un 
objectif » (Dewey 1895,  170-1, nous traduisons), mais elle représente 
surtout, comme nous le verrons, un « élément moteur et [un] élément

Davantage, alors que dans les articles de 1894 et 1895, l’émotion est 
la manifestation  comportementale  d’une « activité divisée » ou d’une 
« lutte » (Dewey 1894,  156), dans  L’art comme expérience  (2005) elle 
contribue utilement et est une partie intégrante de l’accomplissement  du 
processus d’enquête né d’une situation problématique.  Whitehouse 
(1978) considère ainsi que c’est dans ce dernier ouvrage que l’on 
trouve l’aboutissement  de la théorie des émotions que Dewey a 
élaborée tout au long de son œuvre prolifique (Dewey 1922  ; 1930 ; 
1993 ; 2011a ; 2011b ; 2012) 4. C’est aussi, comme le souligne Quéré 
(2012), à ce moment précis que Dewey développe véritablement la 
question essentielle du « travail des émotions » ou de leur « opérativité » 
(Quéré 2013),  au sens de ce qu’elles  accomplissent  et transforment au cours 
de l’expérience.
La théorie des émotions de Dewey a été mobilisée dans de 
nombreuses disciplines – comme par exemple dans les sciences de 
l’éducation (Hohr 2013),  en sciences cognitives (Cunningham 1995  ; 
Johnson 2006), en philosophie (Garrison 2003 ; Mendonça 2012),

Dans l’analyse de John Dewey, les émotions ne sont pas des

associées à une situation spécifique et à une relation particulière.

proposés par Quéré 2015.  Sur ce que Dewey « doit » à Charles Peirce, autour de l’expérience

John Dewey particularly evokes the most 
mundane experiences that we have in our daily lives: walking, reading, tasting, etc. The experience therefore concerns the artist as much as the scientist, the craftsman, the producer, the consumer
or the spectator 6.
Dewey considers, however, that it is undoubtedly in the artistic or aesthetic domain that the most complete, deepest and most intense form of human experience is realized 7. From an inclusive reading (Dreon 2017) of Dewey's work, we can consider that the aesthetic experience and the emotion that accompanies it have a profoundly "ordinary" nature that does not differ,
conceptually, from that found in our daily life experiences (Formis 2015).

However, not everything lends itself to 
experience in our everyday lives. Similarly, ordinary experience can be imperfect or incomplete. This leads us to address a third central point, which is that of the role of emotion in the quality of experience itself. 
In Dewey's pragmatic philosophy, the opposite of 
experience is the absence of unity, the impossibility of re-elaboration of a primary emotion from which experience is woven. 6. John Dewey particularly compares the activity of the artist to that of the mechanic: 
“[t]he intelligent mechanic involved in his work, seeking to do it well, and finding
satisfaction in his work, taking care of his materials and tools with
genuine affection, is involved in his task in the manner of an artist” (AE, 33).
7. “Art is the living and concrete proof that man is capable of restoring
consciously, and therefore on the level of meaning, the union of meaning, need,
impulse and action that characterizes the living being” (AE, 65).

Emotion itself has a responsibility in the incompleteness of
this experience. To simplify, the experience is imperfect when
the emotion that underlies it is either 1) insufficient or inappropriate, or
2) excessive and eruptive.
1) The incompleteness or imperfection of the experience can first of all come from
insufficient or inappropriate stimulation that harms
the individual's engagement in the experience. This is the case, for example,
in boredom or in passivity. This is also the case when emotional habits are a hindrance to the experience of individual psychological resistance, stereotypes and/or restrictive social and cultural norms. Emotion is what allows us to break with habit. But it can also happen that an emotional routine freezes us in a posture that prevents any transformation. This refers in particular to the many situations identified by sociologists in which the production of emotions, sometimes orchestrated by individuals, sometimes suggested or mobilized by the market, aim to preserve a reputation, a social identity, self-esteem or a good conscience (Cabana and Illouz 2018). 2) Too much emotion can also be a hindrance to
experience: according to Dewey, "a person overwhelmed by an emotion is, by that very fact, incapable of expressing it" (AE, 133).

Pour conclure et pour revenir à la trame de notre discussion,

réflexion, en somme, est l’effort douloureux des habitudes perturbées

Les émotions sont évoquées chez les pères fondateurs de

Elles feront aussi leur apparition chez les économistes de la première

Going beyond the standard vision of the economy of emotions
In the current economy of emotion, it is mainly
conceived as an intense episode that the individual is able to
identify. This is particularly the case of fear or anger.
Emotions are differentiated from mood, whose origin is
more diffuse, and whose duration is longer. But also from feeling, which corresponds to the more
subjective part of emotion.

The France Telecom case
In December 2019, the France Telecom case ended with a
decision by the court, convicting the company’s former CEO, Didier
Lombard, the former number 2, Louis-Pierre Wenèse and the former director
of human resources, Olivier Barberot, for “institutional moral harassment”. All three were sentenced to one year in prison
(including 8 months suspended), a sentence to which was added a €15,000 fine
for the defendants and a €75,000 fine for the company.
Four other people, members of the management, were also
found to be accomplices. The trial focused on the company’s transformation plans, Next and Act, aimed at reducing staff by 22,000 employees and mobilizing 10,000 more between 2007 and 2010. As the civil party’s lawyers pointed out during the trial, the company’s management policy deliberately sought to push employees out, “out the door or out the window,” according to the expression used by Didier Lombard himself at a management meeting in 2006. Given the civil servant status of a large proportion of the employees, the policy therefore consisted of exerting maximum pressure on them to force them to leave the company. This policy is in fact part of a standard logic during this period where stress management rules are based on a set of routines concerning decision-making and time management which lock individuals into a preconceived behavioural pattern (Einarsen et al.

The case apparently started with a letter from one of the victims of

of geographical transfers, forced functional transfers, pay cuts, etc., aimed at making employees leave. Beyond the verdict against the defendants, already mentioned, the
court opened the possibility for the 13,000 employees of the company

to demonstrate the damage, by monetary compensation
of between €10,000 and €45,000. France Télécom, which has since become Orange,
could have a heavy price to pay to its former employees. But the most important legal consequence of this trial was the
recognition of the term "institutional moral harassment".
This notion goes beyond the already recognized one of moral harassment, which
implies the designation of the responsibility of clearly identified individuals. With institutional moral harassment, it is the
company's very policy that is called into question, in particular
the human resources management policy. This is a
significant step forward in the recognition of managerial effects
on employees.
It involves a change in management rules. With it, management through stress, which has become commonplace since the 2000s, is generally called into question.

5.3. Emotions as a vector of change
Would the France Télécom affair have existed without the emotion
of indignation and stupefaction that it aroused? "The exceptional
character of this trial is certainly due, in part, to the violence
of the practices of the hierarchy between 2006 and 2008, but it is also due, for a large part, to the movement of social transformation by which the members of the company brought these practices into the public debate, to make visible, explain and denounce their human consequences and to demand another vision of the company and of work" (Florence Palpacuer, Le Monde, June 11, 2019). Workplace suicides obviously trigger extremely strong emotions, of which Michel Deparis' letter was a high point that triggered the indictment. They aroused waves of emotions but also movements of resistance and mobilization. Palpacuer and Seignour (2019), for example, looked at the resistance movement that gave rise to new forms of action, mobilizing academic expertise to measure and qualify the effects of managerial practices that had become abusive. The stress and forced mobility observatory is an emanation of this (Delmas and Merlin 2010).

It 
was a tool to rebuild community in and around the company,
thanks to national meetings which brought together several hundred
actors, union members, academics, doctors, inspectors or experts,
between 2007 and 2008, even before the suicide of Michel Deparis.

seulement l’émotion véhiculée par son témoignage  qui a retenu

travail. L’émotion s’est conjuguée à une expertise. Et on peut penser 
que c’est cette combinaison  de l’émotion et de la parole argumentée 
d’experts qui a  donné tout son poids au procès et à la reconnaissance

Nous retrouvons là les éléments clés de la pensée de Dewey. Plutôt que d’émotions, nous devrions d’ailleurs parler de processus 
émotionnels, tant les émotions se co-construisent et se façonnent dans 
une dynamique interactive entre le sujet et son environnement.  Nous 
retrouvons dans l’affaire France Télécom les éléments de la théorie 
des émotions de Dewey au travers de ce qu’elles accomplissent  dans 
le temps ( i.e., le « travail des émotions »).  Tout d’abord, l’émotion 
nait du trouble affectant le sujet : la vague de suicides dans le cas 
France Télécom. Ensuite, l’émotion est un agent de complétude de 
l’expérience,  de liaison et d’unification  de l’expérience :  au-delà de 
l’émotion brute impliquée par les suicides, des collectifs s’organisent 
pour signaler, documenter,  et finalement porter en justice la situation 
trouble. Enfin, et il s’agit d’une caractéristique  importante pour le 
dénouement  du trouble, le rôle disruptif de l’émotion est à relier au 
fait que l’expérience est avant tout une projection dans le temps, l’idée 
d’un futur. Quéré (2012) souligne parfaitement  que l’émotion est, 
chez Dewey, liée au fait que le sujet se préoccupe de l’évolution et de 
l’issue incertaines de l’événement qui cause le trouble. Autrement dit, 
l’expérience qui se produit dans le présent ne prend sens que parce 
qu’elle est une projection dans le futur. L’émotion est vécue en un 
moment de transaction où l’individu comme son environnement 
se transforme pour produire une autre émotion (plus positive). Là où l’économie des émotions propose un raisonnement  statique, 
instantané, John Dewey propose une analyse dynamique des émotions qui prend en compte l’histoire de la relation. Et c’est pour cette raison 
que les institutions ne sont pas figées mais évoluent avec les émotions 
qu’elles génèrent. Ce que l’affaire France Télécom illustre bien par le 
changement de règle de droit qu’elle a produit. À quoi  bon un procès 
s’il n’avait aucune répercussion  ! Au-delà de la reconnaissance  de leur 
souffrance, les victimes et leurs familles attendent certainement que cela ne se reproduise pas. La dynamique de l’émotion est consubstantielle 
à celle du changement dans les institutions ; ce que Dewey défend.

CONCLUSION
La philosophie  de l’expérience  de John Dewey apparaît plus 
comme une analyse du changement dans les institutions que comme 
une analyse des habitudes, ce à quoi le pragmatisme a été ramené dans certaines lectures insistant sur son parallèle avec l’institutionnalisme. 
Dewey introduit les émotions pour penser les trajectoires disruptives 
dans les institutions. Il souligne en particulier la complémentarité étroite de l’émotion et de la raison dans la transformation  des institutions : 
« Dire que les émotions ne s’allient pas à l’intelligence  sont aveugles 
est une banalité. De même, les émotions intenses peuvent s’exprimer 
par la destruction des institutions. Mais si l’on cherche à améliorer les institutions, seule l’alliance de l’émotion et de l’intelligence est un gage de progrès  » 
(Dewey 2011a,  171, nous soulignons). Dewey complète ainsi l’analyse 
institutionnaliste traditionnelle qui se focalise en priorité sur le rôle des habitudes et la routinisation des institutions. Nous avons illustré l’apport de Dewey par l’exemple de l’affaire France Télécom dont 
le procès a abouti en 2019 à un changement  significatif dans les 
règles de droit relatives à la gestion des ressources humaines dans les entreprises en France.

Dewey’s thinking shows us, through this example, that institutionalism could be enriched by a theory of
emotions that makes room for change in institutions.
Our example nevertheless raises at least one question to which we have not answered: are emotions only
an individual phenomenon, which can possibly be aggregated, or should we think of them as collective emotions, which would go beyond the framework of a simple aggregation? The answer to this
question is certainly not trivial since it has implications for the way in which change occurs.
It goes far beyond what this article wanted to highlight.

The collective of articles published by Kaufmann and Quéré (2020) on collective emotions
offer many relevant reflections to help answer this question. In the continuity of our article and this collective work, a next step for us is to examine the way in which Dewey thinks (or does not think) about the relationship between emotions and the collective and to establish the link with a possible conception of collective emotions.

Since Elster’s seminal review [1998], an abundant literature has revealed the growing interest of economists in the question of emotions. Developing a richer and more complete economy of emotions makes it necessary to also draw on other approaches to emotion, notably from sociology, anthropology, history and philosophy. The aim of this article is to contribute to enriching the work of economists in this field by proposing a multidisciplinary state of the art that synthesizes the knowledge derived from the theory of emotions. The first step is to identify the major stages in the construction of this theory and to extract the essential properties of emotions. The aim is then to illustrate how this knowledge has been mobilized in economic analysis, taking into account the diversity of approaches characteristic of the discipline.

Introduction
Since Elster's seminal review [1998], an abundant literature has
revealed the growing interest of economists in the question of emotions (Loewenstein [2000], Camerer et al.

[2005], Rick et Loewenstein [2008],
Lerner et al.
[2015], Petit [2009, 2015], Dunning et al.

[2017], Gomes [2017],
Winter [2017], Wälde et Moors [2017], Tkach [2019], Rolls [2019]).

As in many academic disciplines, economists have accompanied what historians have called "the emotional turn" (Plam-per [2010]), an extraordinary craze born in the mid-1990s for the study of emotions. In economics, emotions are today mainly mobilized and studied in an experimental framework and then introduced into behavioral models in order to improve existing models of human behavior. The "economics of emotions" (Petit [2015]) has made it possible to "revisit" the model of perfect rationality (Elster [1996], Kahneman [2012], Rolls [2019]), has introduced a plurality of social and/or moral motivations (Jourdheuil and Petit [2015]) and has led to new modalities of intervention by public authorities such as emotional paternalism (Schultz et al. [2007]). The introduction of emotion into economic analysis was carried out
essentially from a psychological and neurological conception of emotion. As suggested by Elster [1998], this conception made it possible (i) to disturb emotion in categories that could be easily mobilized by economists, (ii) to give it a functional (multi-component) definition particularly adapted to the methodological individualism practiced in experimental and behavioral economics and above all (iii) to provide precise and effective instruments for measuring and inducing emotions. The theory of emotions that was gradually established during the 20th century, however, covers a much broader field of analysis than that taken into account by psychology and neuroscience. Other disciplines – such as sociology, philosophy, anthropology, history or literature – have also constructed an elaborate and fruitful theory of emotions. Recent work on the theory of emotions also shows that there is now a convergence between approaches that were once opposed and considered incompatible (biology vs. anthropology, psychology vs. sociology). Developing a richer and more complete “economy of emotions” makes it necessary to know and draw on the different approaches to emotion, without limiting ourselves to the sole conception of psychology and/or neurology. The aim of this review is therefore to contribute to enriching the work of economists in this field by proposing a multidisciplinary state of the art that synthesizes the knowledge derived from the theory of emotions. First, it is a question of identifying the main stages in the construction of this theory and extracting the essential properties of emotions (2). The aim then is to illustrate – as extensively as possible but without claiming to be exhaustive – how this knowledge has been used in economic analysis, taking into account the diversity of approaches characteristic of the discipline (3). We will conclude this review of the literature on the theory and economics of emotions by discussing and identifying the most fruitful and promising areas of research for economists (4).

The science of emotions:
expression, behavior, and social construction
It is possible to juxtapose two major conceptions in contemporary scientific approaches to emotion23. First, there are the authors who consider that emotions correspond to an objective empirical reality that can be defined, analyzed, evaluated, and broken down. Schematically, the proponents of this first trend are more located in the life sciences, in the medical sciences, or in experimental sciences such as psychology or neuroscience. Within this first trend, there are, on the one hand, those who give primacy to the bodily, physiological, biological dimension of emotion (2.1) and, on the other hand, those who, by relativizing the scope of the body, reveal the importance of cognition and psychological processes (2.2). Other authors, on the contrary, argue that emotions should be considered rather as objects on which we can formulate a discourse without claiming an operational measurement.

These authors share the idea that the human mind bases its capacity for knowledge on relationships

However, the reader must keep in mind that the porosity, contiguity and overlap between the work of researchers belonging to different disciplines (neurology, sociology, social psychology, anthropology, philosophy, etc.) is much greater than what the following presentation of the theory of emotions suggests. The physiological and biological dimension
of emotion
The first scientific approach to the theory of emotions emphasizes
the physiological, biological and universal dimension of emotion.

We can summarize it by saying that emotion is located in the body and that consequently emotions can be produced, expressed and recognized by any human, regardless of their culture. An emotion like fear, for example, would have this universal, innate, natural dimension, which is manifested by certain facial expressions (tensing) or body expressions (trembling, cold sweat, palpitations, etc.).
For a very long time, many thinkers have sought to locate
emotion in the body.

This is the case of several Greek authors (Hippocrates, Galen), Romans, ecclesiastical theologians (Augustine, Thomas Aquinas), but also of Descartes [1649], Condillac [1754], Smith [1759] or Diderot and d'Alembert [1765].

However, it is thanks to Darwin's theory of evolution [1872] that bodily theories of emotion receive a major boost. In Darwin's naturalistic approach [1872], emotions are conceived as current vestiges of the distant origins of the human species.

They serve the organism by allowing it to react with appropriate behaviors to dangers from the environment. For example, in the case of surprise, opening the eyes and fixing the gaze would facilitate the detection and identification of unexpected events.

Emotions also have a primary function of social communication or signaling when, through the body, they reveal the intentions of living beings. The universality of emotions is assessed by the recognition of facial expressions across different cultures; it generates so-called "basic" emotions that are universally shared (such as fear, anger, surprise, disgust, joy and sadness). text: The psychologist William James, unanimously recognized as the father of American psychology, and the anatomist Carl Lange, propose an analysis that is certainly in line with the English naturalist, but which provides an explanation of the psychological mechanisms underlying emotion.
James-Lange's thesis is as revolutionary as it is counter-intuitive.

These authors put forward the idea that physiological and bodily changes, as well as the behaviors associated with them, are not the "consequence" of emotion (as common sense and classical approaches of the time claim) but the "cause". According to this conception, becoming aware of these physiological changes constitutes the emotion in itself. For example, when we realize that we are in danger, this perception triggers a set of bodily responses and it is our awareness of these responses that constitutes fear.
This is what James [1884] sums up by saying that "we are sad because we cry" or that "we are afraid because we find that we tremble."

James-Lange's theory has had a singular career.

On the one hand, it quickly became the highly visible "flag" of a nascent psychological science. On the other hand, it spontaneously underwent numerous criticisms and was unable to lead to a proposal that would achieve consensus within the scientific community.

In particular, for Cannon [1927], the main opponent of the so-called "peripheralist" theory (allusion to the fact that the source of emotion comes from bodily manifestations located on the periphery), the latter cannot distinguish what relates to emotion and what is dissociated from it, is incapable of differentiating emotions from each other (intense joy, great fear or great sadness generating the same bodily modifications), and finally gives disproportionate weight to the bodily component to the detriment of cognitive aspects.

Cannon [1927] then states a central theory of emotion which posits that its seat resides where no one had yet located it, that is to say, in the regions situated under the cerebral cortex (called "subcortical") and, in particular, at the level of the "thalamus".

From these regions originate parallel innervations that trigger physiological responses on the one hand and subjective emotional experience on the other.
The interest of the “James-Lange” proposition and the work of its opponents is to fuel the debate on the nature of the relationship between emotion and cognition throughout the 20th century. It will find, in part, its resolution in the work of Schachter [1964] who adds to the “physiological arousal” specific to emotion a “cognitive labeling”, dependent on the context, and thus allows to admit the undifferentiated aspect of physical manifestations. As we see later, this marks the explicit beginning of cognitive and psychosocial theories of emotions (2.2). Another issue – concerning the primacy (or not) of emotion over cognition – will also feed the renewal of psychological theories of emotion in the 1980s. The presupposition of social psychologist Robert Zajonc is that the first reaction to an object or a person is an emotional (adaptive) reaction that can lead to a cognitive reaction. While for cognitive psychologist Richard Lazarus, cognition is a necessary condition for emotion and would therefore come first. The misunderstanding ultimately concerns how to define cognition.

text: Damasio [1995] fully embodies this renewal.

In the theory he proposes, the individual begins by unconsciously apprehending the relevant elements of a situation or those of his close environment, which provokes cerebral reactions as well as peripheral or vagal modifications. As in James [1884], it is when he becomes aware of these reactions that the individual becomes aware of the emotion. According to Damasio [1995], when a similar situation arises, it evokes the central cerebral representations of the body image linked to these peripheral modifications. These representations thus play the role of "somatic markers" which allow, when we are again faced with similar situations or events, to immediately become aware of the emotion, and to associate with it traits of appropriate action behaviors. The marker would therefore function as an emotional memory, an emotional labeling of the event or landscape, as a warning or encouragement signal (innate or acquired) of cognitive and unconscious origin.
Damasio's thesis [1995] found a very favorable echo in the academic world because it managed to convincingly overturn the preconceived idea that emotions would be a disruptor of decision-making.
Ledoux [1998] is also one of those who have enabled the rehabilitation of emotions that we call “visceral”.

It shows that in emergency situations (fire, aggression, predation, etc.), our perception of danger first passes through our emotional brain (via the amygdala) before being redirected a quarter of a second later to the prefrontal cortex.

The existence of this short subcortical circuit allows the organism to react quickly to elementary configurations of emotional stimuli, in the absence of elaborate perception and recognition. Emotion, more than reason, is vital here. In fact, the rigid opposition between reason and emotion is no longer claimed by any of the theorists of emotion. We can no longer oppose reason and emotion, cognitive and volitional faculties on the one hand and bodily and unconscious affectivity on the other, as Western thought has done for centuries. Emotions, on the contrary, appear to be necessary for human beings to be able to pursue long-term planned activities, to be able to react adequately to events and to maintain with others the relationships without which no practical rationality is possible.
They therefore have an impact that can be direct, but also indirect and unconscious, and which is very often useful for individual decision-making.
2.2.

The cognitive dimension of emotion
In contrast to those who describe emotion entirely (or primarily) through its bodily and biological dimension, cognitive authors and philosophers of the mind go so far as to say that emotion is nothing other than a manifestation of thought. Schematically, this underlies the idea that, for an emotion to be provoked, the object on which the emotion bears must affect or involve the individual according to his or her life, experience, expectations, interests or objectives.
Committed to the continuity of the cognitive turn in linguistics, the science of emotions experienced a profound renewal of its approaches in the second half of the 20th century.

Heir to Aristotle's thinking, initiated by Arnold [1960] and by the "cognitive-physiological" theory of Schachter [1964], the cognitive approach flourished from the beginning of the 1980s, bringing together psychologists (Nico Frijda, Herbert Simon, Andrew Ortony, Gerald Clore and Allan Collins, Keith Oatley and Philip Johnson-Laird), but also influential philosophers (Ronald de Sousa, Robert Solomon, Jon Elster).

These authors share the idea that emotions are not passions that we passively undergo – Solomon [1976] notably denounced the “hydraulic” version of the physiological current of emotion – and affirm on the contrary that we are actively involved in their fabrication.
The story begins with the proposition of Magda Arnold, a researcher of Austrian origin who emigrated to the United States, who relays the idea that perception is always the place of an encounter between a sensation and the expectations of a subject.

In this sense, perception is never neutral because it always involves a certain "coloring" of the subject's relationship to the object he perceives. This coloring is what Arnold [1960] calls an "appraisal" of the affective stimulation. Such an "appreciation" is manifested by an emotional attitude (disgust, fear, anger) that sets in almost as quickly as the perception itself, arousing nervous impulses from the cortex to the centers of the thalamus and the hypothalamus.
These centers in turn activate specific modules of facial expression, physiological changes and subjective experience.

A secondary evaluation phase then results from the awareness of these different changes that are evaluated as desirable or not.
In this context, emotion is associated with a “tendency to action”, according to Frijda’s expression [1986], which is more a preparation for action (a potentiality) than an automatic behavior. Frijda [1986] here skillfully reconciles the phenomenological idea that emotions have an intentional aim (as suggested by Sartre [1938]) and the evolutionary conceptionEmmanuel Petit— ...
Guilt would thus incite us to repair (a wrong), desire to destroy (the desired object), fear would urge us to attack (the aggressor), to flee or even to faint.
A tendency to action can thus give rise (but not necessarily) to a whole range of differentiated behaviors depending on the situation.

This depends, if we follow Scherer [2005], on the nature of the evaluation process in progress: is the situation new, pleasant or unpleasant, in line with our objectives or not?
In line with the theory of "evaluation" (Arnold [1960]), many authors (often philosophers) consider that emotions are more than a simple appreciation (of an event, of a behavior) or a moral judgment: they are also "revealers" of our values.

Livet [2002] defends in particular the idea that emotion results from the gap, the differential, between reality as we perceive it and our expectations, our preferences or our desires. The existence of this emotional differential provokes a necessary work of "revision" which aims to align our perception of the world with what the world tells us objectively. Emotion thus serves us, like an alarm signal, to re-evaluate our priorities in the medium term or to readjust our objectives when reality does not conform to what we expect of it. Emotion is a form of guide that allows us to adapt to our environment, like “somatic markers” (Damasio [1995]). However, when we chronically and systematically resist this revision process, and the emotion repeats itself (whether it is disappointment, anger or any other emotion), it reveals to us the importance that we give to particular desires, beliefs or preferences, which in fact correspond to our most deeply rooted values ​​that we do not wish to give up. The dynamics of emotion generated by this gap between values ​​and perceived reality show that emotion can be a way of accessing the value systems of the individual (but also those of the group) by taking into account the resistance to change as well as the desire for change.

The place of emotion in economic analysis: behavior, society, institutions
The introduction of emotions into economic analysis is a particularly recent phenomenon in light of the construction of the theory of emotions mentioned in the first part of our review. Favoring the analysis of individual behavior, the experimental and behavioral approach in economics (3.1) has mobilized a psychological and bio-logical conception (2.1 and 2.2) that describes emotion essentially as an autonomous or purely internal phenomenon. On the other hand, economic sociology (3.2) has drawn on the achievements of the sociological and anthropological approach to emotions (2.3) in order to show how social and cultural dynamics shape the emotional attitudes of individuals. For institutional economics (3.3), if the introduction of emotions remains a relatively unexplored field (Patalano [2010]), recent work reveals why emotion plays a major role in the transformation of institutions via modifications of individual behaviors. 3.1.

text: The memory of fear can therefore be persistent because it is unconscious in nature. As suggested by work on “post-memory” (Hirsch [2017]), the emotional power of certain traumatic events (such as fratricidal wars or epidemics) is so strong that these events that occurred in the past see their effects continue unconsciously in the present within generations that did not experience them. A central question concerning fear is how an individual can regulate it, control it when its origin may be unconscious in nature.

Psychologists who work on these issues know that one cannot eliminate an emotion, that it is very complex to oust it or to "compensate" for it with another (as many philosophers proposed in the 18th century (see Hirschman [1977])) and that, in this matter, cognitive effort or even financial incentive are not very operational (Ler-ner et al.

Work in psychology has shown, for example, how difficult it can be to “decondition” a pathology linked to fear, such as intense stress induced by an episode of fright or various forms of phobias (Rimé [2015]).

The environment, institutions, and context play a central role here, promoting (or not) this learning. The approach of historians (Delumeau [1978], Robin [2008]) reminds us in particular of the weight of institutions in the social construction of fear. A climate of collective fear established by a particular event (September 11, 2001) can lead to the acceptance of public policies in different spheres of public or private life (Internet surveillance activity, restriction of mobility, freedoms and modes of expression, censorship, etc.), even if they are not linked to the original fear.
This is made possible because the initial emotion lastingly modifies the perception of individual risk (Lerner et al.

[2003]).
To counteract the effects of fear, it is therefore not a question of avoiding
risk at all times but of cultivating it (Pope et al.

[2006]), not to rely on “expert systems” which deprive individuals of the experience of decision-making, or even not to fully engage our resources (economic, human, emotional, military) and our organizational systems, in anticipation of a hazard, a crisis (economic or health).

“Getting out of the empire of fear” (Delumeau [1978]) is therefore more about knowing it and taming it.

As we have however mentioned regarding the emotion of fear, the behavioral approach is limited by a conception of emotion which is limited to the description of a psychological state and which does not integrate (or barely) the social, historical or cultural aspects specific to the emotion. Pecchenino’s recent contribution [2011, 2015] – drawing in particular on philosophical, theological and psychological conceptions of hope (and its antithesis, despair) – shows, however, that it is possible to model the main characteristics of this counterfactual emotion: hope holds out the prospect of a possibility, of accessible objectives; it notably accentuates the value of the future (in relation to the present), is not irrational from the moment when the individual is capable of correctly filtering the information transmitted to him, represents a force for change (at the level of the individual and society) as well as an ability to mobilize individual effort; hope also depends crucially on the quality of the social bond (the absence of which can, on the contrary, give rise to despair). This reading of hope – from which, in our opinion, useful lessons can be extracted in the context of the health crisis that humanity has been experiencing since the beginning of 2020 – shows that the initial reductive conception of emotion in behavioral economics can be overcome. Similarly, the innovative approach proposed by Thoron [2017] – which emphasizes the relational capacity of emotion – or that of van Winden [2012, 2015] – which insists on the existence of affective-social links between agents (see Petit [2018] for a review) – indicate a possible overcoming (or extension) of this initial orientation. This extension can notably be inspired, in the field of economic analysis, by other approaches that have explored the question of emotions, as is the case in economic sociology (3.2) or the economics of institutions (3.3). 3.2. Economic sociology or the control of emotions
The rejection of pure rationality and the absence of consideration of the social and
culture constitute unifying elements of the sociological approach to emotions (2.3). This approach has benefited from the founding works around the sociology of rituals (Parsons [1937]), interactionist thought (Goffman [1974]), relational sociology (Laflamme [1995]) or even the anthropological communication approach (Bateson [1991]) (see Berezin [2006] and Bernard [2017] for reviews).
In support of this literature, economic sociology has integrated emotion in order to explore new questions (Etzioni [1988]; Pixley [2002, 2012]).

Two themes bring together a large part of this literature (mainly carried by sociologists) which starts from the principle that individual emotions are shaped by society. One questions the control, imposed by the market and companies, of employees' emotions (3.2.1). The other highlights the way in which the market itself produces and sells emotion (3.2.2).
3.2.1. Emotions under control
During the 20th century, the development of capitalism led to the
development of an entrepreneurial culture that gave a central place to emotional life in companies and organizations. By integrating affects, economic logic transformed the traditional divisions – reason/emotion, public/private, masculine/feminine – that had prevailed until then. In the mid-1930s, the scientific approach to regulating emotions met with a very strong demand from companies wishing to develop worker performance.

text: Mayo [1933] is a pioneer here: he conducted a famous experiment in the Western Electric Company factories in Hawthorne from 1924 to 1927, which revealed that employee productivity increased when work relations took into account the workers' emotions.
Mayo opens the way to a period in which the economic sphere can no longer be considered an emotional desert.

Corporate culture gradually integrates human relations, self-enhancement techniques, emotional control and measurement, various communication tools, in order to establish a climate of trust, cooperation or a sense of belonging to the institution (Illouz [2009]).
Since that time, the process of controlling employees' emotions has continued to grow. The concept of "emotional intelligence", highlighted by Goleman [1998], has thus become, within the company, a classic instrument for classifying (and therefore hierarchizing) employees' emotional skills, which partly determines their access to responsibilities, the advancement procedure concerning them, the bonuses to which they are entitled as well as the definition of their organizational role.
However, today we no longer talk about “control” but more about regulation or listening to one’s emotions.

Personal development cultivated within the company itself contributes greatly to this self-regulation. It is supervised by “soul managers” (Brunel [2016]) who promote the idea of ​​self-realization and individual freedom.
We praise the virtues of autonomy, of “letting go” and of fulfillment at work.
Joy, play, complicity, etc., are popular.

Employee well-being has thus become the key to understanding the new management of human resources at the beginning

Well-being and pleasure at work are, however, at the service of
an efficiency objective.

Lordon [2013] sees in recent managerial psychology the awareness, within the productive system, that it is more profitable to govern by joy than by fear. Capitalism has found a use for the management of emotions and has organized it effectively.

This particularly concerns a category of service professions (secretaries, nurses, cashiers, etc.) in which “emotional work” – the (forced) smile of the flight attendant or cashier, the sobriety of the undertaker, the (feigned) joviality of the shopkeeper or secretary – is used by companies and directed towards commercial ends (Hochschild [2017]).

Emotion management is done by promoting a “genuine” smile, by training employees to produce such a smile, by supervising their production, and even by creating a link between this “activity” and the profit that companies generate. Those who perform emotional labor when they provide a service are, just like those who perform physical labor by manufacturing objects, subject to the same rules of mass production.
From then on, the “house is no longer a refuge against the abuses linked to the search for profit, and for its part, the market relies on the imaginary of the house” (Hochs-child [2017, p.
177]), as when airlines use the idea that stewardesses are “like a family” in the aircraft cabin and that the emotions they are supposed to experience there are of the same nature.

Economic sociology thus highlights the potential social and psychological consequences induced by “emotional work”, which sometimes results in professional exhaustion.
3.2.2. Emotions for sale
It may seem strange that we can attribute a price to emotion and
that affectivity is itself a commercial issue. Jeudy-Ballini [2004] nevertheless mentioned the existence of a “price” for the expression of emotion within the Sulka community in Papua New Guinea: when a sulka intentionally provokes a negative emotion (anger, shame, etc.) in another, the latter is expected to claim material compensation. The most paradoxical thing is that, even in the presence of an emotion with a positive valence (such as admiration or delight), the emotional impact induced – for example, in a spectator by the beauty of a mask, a song or a dance – can be the subject of a request for compensation as soon as the person experiencing it makes a statement about it (Derlon and Jeudy-Ballini [2008]).
In the market system, such a price does not exist. However, it is easy to understand that a poker player who has poor control over his emotions at a table will quickly lose a lot of money.

More generally, managers have long shown that expressions of emotions have a significant impact on the outcome of negotiations (Morris and Keltner [2000]), as can be the case in particular with anger (Sinaceur and Tie-dens [2006]), sadness (Sinaceur et al. [2015]) or even when the negotiator's emotions are unpredictable (Sinaceur et al.

Similarly, we can consider that emotional work, if it is valued by companies, corresponds to a cost integrated into the service or product intended for consumers or users. Since companies have oriented emotional work towards commercial ends, the latter have largely become accustomed to the play of superficial emotions that characterize the social or professional environment.
Even though it is often a fairly inauthentic work, it is appreciated by the public for which it is intended and valued as such.

One of the challenges of expressing emotions through artificial intelligence or robots lies precisely in the bet of this valorization of emotion (Robinson and Kaliouby [2009], Petit [2021b]).
To these (non-exhaustive) elements of valorization must be added the fact (studied relatively recently) that emotion is now for sale in the commercial sphere in the form of an "affective experience" (Fil-ser [2015]).
A significant part of marketing activities is geared towards an “experiential” design of the good or service offered.

The “forager” is thus someone who comes to a point of sale, without the intention of purchasing, in search of a pleasurable experience (for example, to discover new things, to mingle with the crowd or even simply to touch, listen or taste).

The tourism sector perfectly illustrates this dimension in the sense that traveling, at the beginning of the 21st century, means looking for moments that are as emotionally intense as they are memorable (Veneyre[2016]).
To travel is to have an “authentic” experience, it is to be amazed.

Finally, but this time in a more critical but also more extensive manner, Illouz [2019] denounces the excesses of the expansion of the market into the intimate sphere – as Zelizer [2000] initially did – by noting that if the purchase of goods allows one to “experience” emotions, the emotions themselves have been transformed into goods.

The contribution of the institutionalist approach:
cognition and emotion
The institutionalist project highlights the role of institutions in economic analysis – their formation as well as their transformation – and starts from a conception of the human that goes beyond both his interest and his pure reason (Chavance [2018]). This project thus aims to introduce a process – emotion – which is (1) a connection between the individual and institutions, (2) which transforms both in a dynamic and continuous way and which, moreover (3) is capable of doing so in a non-conscious way as we have underlined in the first part of this review.
3.3.1. The intuitions of the founders
In the works of the founders of institutionalism at the beginning of the
20th century – whether Thorstein Veblen or John Commons –
emotion has been relatively little mobilized.
Certainly, Veblen repeatedly appeals to instincts (Hodgson [2007], Almeida [2015]) while Emmanuel Petit— ...
390, our emphasis], man "is originally a being of passion [...] for whom freedom and reason are a matter of the slow evolution of moral character and the constraint imposed by government."

At the time, the accumulated knowledge on the question of emotions probably did not allow these authors to go further.
In the 1950s, however, progress in cognitive psychology (see
2.2.) would encourage reflection on the scope of emotion.
Two of the major references of the "new institutional economics" - Herbert Simon and Friedrich Hayek - have thus developed a relevant and elaborate analysis of the role of emotion in the human mind.

Inspired in particular by Gestalt, Hayek [1952] proposes, in The Sensory Order, a theory of the mind that mobilizes sensory perceptions as much as the emotions of individuals. Hayek [1952] anticipates in particular the progress of contemporary cognitive sciences (and in particular connectionism) on which the "cognitive" approach of the institutions of Denzau and North [1994] will be based.

3.3.4. Perspectives
The integration of emotions into the study of institutions is, for economists, a recent issue.

If, for example, the evolutionary and mechanical approach of Winter [2017] – which defines emotion only in opposition to reason – reveals the minor place that can sometimes be attributed to it (see however Bowles and Gintis [2011]), the contribution of Markey-Towler [2018] seems much more promising.
Markey-Towler [2018] returns to the pre-psychological conditions that must exist for institutions to determine behavior.

In particular, it highlights the role that emotions play in conformity to institutions. In this sense, his approach is inspired by the sociological approach to emotions (2.3) but also by the theory of organizations that we have just mentioned (3.3.3) as well as the model of Denzau and North [1994]. The conceptualization work of Markey-Towler [2018] thus shows that there is a potential for introducing emotion into the institutionalist approach that is based on the intersection of related literatures. 4. Scope and challenges of the economics
of emotions for the discipline
Our review of the literature on the introduction of the theory of emotions
into economic analysis has shown that this abundant literature is now based on an open and multidisciplinary conception of emotion: to the conventional approaches of biology and psychology are added studies in the social and human sciences around sociology, anthropology but also history and naturally philosophy. Apprehended in a more global and more complete way, emotion has thus been introduced both in the field of experimental and behavioral economics but also progressively in economic sociology or by institutionalist authors. It thus emerges from our review that the most recent "economics of emotions" has largely benefited from an in-depth theoretical knowledge of the science of emotions. Emotion is thus no longer perceived as an alteration of reason.
Its social and cultural dimension is recognized.

Its versatility – action on beliefs, behaviors or values ​​– is evident in many works.
The diagnosis of the scope and usefulness of introducing emotions into
economics cannot, however, be limited to this positive observation and must be204—————————— Theory of emotions and economic analysis: a review

In our review, we have sought to bring together a broad literature on this issue within standard economics, economic sociology and institutional economics.

Within these currents of analysis, the interest, and probably the usefulness for the discipline, of introducing emotion is of a rather different nature.
In economic sociology, for example, the many works on emotions identify useful points of application for economists (the market of emotions or emotions in the market) as well as a notional basis (emotional intelligence, trust, management of emotions within the company, phenomena of exhaustion at work, social control of affect) often too little mobilized by standard theory.
This work usefully supports more conceptual or applied work.

In this sense, they reinforce economic analysis and can also be a source of inspiration.
In behavioral economics, the challenge is more, around the question of decision-making, to experiment in order to better grasp the part of emotion in individual attitudes.
There is also a strong modeling issue, this being a trademark of the discipline in its most dominant component.

We have certainly identified the methodological limits of the standard approach based on the emotion of fear. The example of regret, however, shows how far we have come since the first exploratory works. It appears that behavioral economists favor a "discreet" (and often universal) (psychological) reading of emotion, identifying the effects of a particular emotion (envy, anger, guilt, etc.) based on a multi-component logic (Scherer [2005]). This is an undeniable asset but it is also a limitation of the analysis when, taking into account the polymorphic nature of emotion (we often make a parallel with color or music), it arises in a specific social and cultural context mixed with other affects (or even other emotions). For many of the problems they face, decision-makers often face a composite of emotions (anger, fear, disgust, resentment, empathy, etc.) that evolves very dynamically and in response to changes in the environment and the emotional changes of others.

The contribution of behavioral economics is therefore reduced since it is based on an exclusively psychological or neurological analysis. This methodological limitation – mainly linked to the focus on the “interiority” specific to emotion – does not allow us to truly address certain social or political issues related to emotions (such as, for example, the origins and manifestations of fear induced by a pandemic within a population). This is particularly the case with the question of the effects of “collective emotions” which requires conceptualization work that philosophy is able to produce (see in particular the excellent presentation made by Salmela [2020]). Following Livet [2002] but also Rimé [2005], it is a question of questioning the way in which an emotion can be "shared" socially, imitated, "aggregated", felt collectively or transmitted, etc., within a community, a population or even a group.
The above leads us to question the scope of emotion
within the institutional economy. As we have suggested, the eco-Emmanuel Petit— ... Paradoxically, this potential has not yet been realized, neither with regard to the “old” institutionalism of John Commons or Thorstein Veblen, nor with regard to neo-institutionalism (Patalano [2010]), emotion remaining to this day in our opinion the missing piece of this current of analysis. Some recent conceptual work, however, suggests that it is possible to “endogenize” individual emotions in such a way as to account for their active role in modifying the subject’s environment. Petit and Ballet [2021], for example, translate this idea of ​​endogeneity using John Dewey’s theory of emotions. For the pragmatist author, emotion signals the need for change and is at the same time an active and central agent in the reconfiguration of individual habits. We can then consider a modification of habits, through emotion, which goes well beyond what the behavioral theory of “nudge” can propose (Thaler and Sunstein [2010]).

Recently, the "France Tele-com case9" is an interesting illustration of how the dynamics of
emotion can lead to a favorable change - via the recognition of "institutional moral harassment" - in the rules that structure the law and life at work.

Beyond this illustration, taking into account emotions (individual or collective) that are endogenous to the course of our lives within institutional frameworks is intended to allow us to better understand societal issues – epidemics, climate change, migration, inequalities, etc. – within which emotions represent a major phenomenon.
5. In conclusion
When, more than thirty years ago, economists began to mobilize the register of emotion in their work, they most often did so in a rather vague way – not making a distinction (as psychologists do today) between mood, emotion and feeling. Furthermore, their analysis was based on scattered, rather undeveloped and imprecise elements of the theory of emotions. Since Elster's seminal review [1998], the introduction of emotion into analysis has received greater attention and has been the subject of a rapidly expanding literature.
